title: Using wowi
text: Acute malnutrition remains critical public health concern, particularly fragile humanitarian settings, often requiring targetted interventions. spatial distribution often uneven, clusters elevated burden. Understanding unusual high-burden areas exist crucial effective planning, resource allocation, early warning systems, timely response alleviate plight affected population. article, learn use wowi R package understand spatial distribution acute malnutrition data set. start walk , important critical concepts belt. identify statistically significant spatial clusters, analysts frequently rely SaTScan, powerful tool spatial spatio-temporal scan statistics. SaTScan‚Äôs Bernoulli model particularly suited binary outcomes : ‚ÄúCase‚Äù = child acutely malnourished ‚ÄúControl‚Äù = child acutely malnourished evaluates whether observed clustering cases exceeds expected chance Martin Kulldorff (July 2022). wowi R package provides tidy, reproducible interface running Bernoulli spatial scan analysis via SaTScan. depends rsatscan R package, enables use SaTScan software within R. rsatscan offers general-purpose functionality, wowi thoughtfully designed acute malnutrition analysis. package returns standard set outputs generated SaTScan: interactive HTML map displaying detected clusters. can opened web browser, user can play - zoom , click bubbles see statistics bubbles . text-based output extension .txt containing results. Additional GIS-based files (e.g., shapefiles) can useful geospatial manipulation integration mapping workflows. Furthermore, also returns tidy table summarising detected clusters, parsed text-based file described point 2. summary enables easier manipulation integration analyst‚Äôs downstream workflow. what: Using wowi to identify spatial clusters of high rates of acute malnutrition
title: Using wowi
text: wowi R package provides tidy, reproducible interface running Bernoulli spatial scan analysis via SaTScan. depends rsatscan R package, enables use SaTScan software within R. rsatscan offers general-purpose functionality, wowi thoughtfully designed acute malnutrition analysis. package returns standard set outputs generated SaTScan: interactive HTML map displaying detected clusters. can opened web browser, user can play - zoom , click bubbles see statistics bubbles . text-based output extension .txt containing results. Additional GIS-based files (e.g., shapefiles) can useful geospatial manipulation integration mapping workflows. what: From data to clusters - the wowi analysis workflow
title: Using wowi
text: analysis workflow wowi begins standard anthropometric data processing steps - data wrangling quality checks. purpose, wowi relies mwana package, installed updated automatically install wowi. Moreover, downstream analysis workflow, sf package required generate shapefile-related outputs. Note sf installed wowi, therefore must install separately. Note wowi function unless SaTScan software installed machine. can download : https://www.satscan.org. installed, copy path SaTScan executable machine. needed R locate run . now begin walkthrough using package‚Äôs built-dataset, anthro. SMART survey dataset includes geographical coordinates - x y columns - along corresponding precision recorded precision column. Note Geographical coordinates indispensable spatial cluster detection ‚Äî without , spatial analysis simply performed. can scan spatial clusters using acute malnutrition case definitions based weight--height z-scores /oedema, mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) /oedema, combined definition. data wrangling workflow configured accordingly. article, demonstrate using former. Hereafter, can check quality data. Learn . handled ww_run_satscan() function. Read full documentation typing ?ww_run_satscan console clicking . can run analysis either single-area multiple-area dataset. begin former, followed latter. 1 Although never use rsatscan package explicitly, must make available environment. creates specific environment object - ssenv. loaded, wowi run. 2 Specify folder like output results analysis saved. 3 Provide path SaTScan GUI installation. varies depending operating system (OS). macOS, typically ‚Äú/Applications/SaTScan.app/Contents/app‚Äù; Windows, ‚ÄúC:/Program Files/SaTScan‚Äù. 4 Indicate name SaTScan batch file. macOS, use ‚Äúsatscan‚Äù; Windows, use ‚ÄúSaTScanBatch64‚Äù. code generate seven files folder specified using dir argument. files share common base name, defined string provided filename argument. .cas, .ctl .geo files SaTScan input datasets representing cases, controls geographical coordinates, respectively. .clustermap.html file interactive HTML visualisation embedded Google Map displaying detected clusters. files related shapefiles can used GIS analysis manipulation. Furthermore, can view results text-based format. , access object assigned results ww_run_satscan(). demo, object called results. see text-based results, use results$.txt. file quite long, purposes demo display first 48 rows. file isn‚Äôt convenient want perform manipulation. Don‚Äôt worry ‚Äî ww_run_satscan() got covered ‚òÇÔ∏è. parses text-based results tidy table can easily work üòé. access , simply subset results object like : results$.df: use dataset containing multiple areas. example dataset, several districts, want run spatial scan district dataset. , set filename argument NULL, set .by_area = TRUE, finally specify column dataset stores areas - district - example. demo, filter just two districts. returns following outputs: can also obtain tidy table:

title: Configure SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan ‚Äî ww_configure_satscan
text: filename quoted string identifying analysis area. params_dir quoted string folder directory parameters file (produced function) saved. can directory specified ww_wrangle_data(). satscan_version quoted string indicating version SaTScan installed user's computer. Internally, value checked latest available version. older, warning issued link SaTScan‚Äôs website. Although analysis interrupted, recommended use latest version. .scan_for quoted string indicating type clusters scan . scan clusters high rates , set .scan_for = "high-rates". scan high low rates, set .scan_for = "high-low-rates".

title: Configure SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan ‚Äî ww_configure_satscan
text: information Bernoulli purely spatial scans, refer SaTScan technical documentation available : https://www.satscan.org/techdoc.html.

title: Configure SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan ‚Äî ww_configure_satscan
text: Kulldorff, M. (2022) SaTScan user guide version 10.1. Available : https://www.satscan.org/.

title: Configure SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan ‚Äî ww_configure_satscan
code: ## Given a temporary directory ---- tmp <- withr::local_tempdir() directory <- file.path(tmp, "input-files")  ## Wrangle data with `{mwana}` ---- x <- anthro |>   dplyr::rename(longitude = y, latitude = x) |>   mwana::mw_wrangle_wfhz(     sex = sex,     .recode_sex = TRUE,     weight = weight,     height = height   ) |>   mwana::define_wasting(     zscores = wfhz,     .by = "zscores",     oedema = oedema   ) #> ================================================================================  ## Apply the function ---- ww_wrangle_data(   .data = x,   filename = "Locality",   dir = directory,   .gam_based = "wfhz",   latitude = latitude,   longitude = longitude ) #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpYJ0E4k/file246448eff81e/input-files/Locality"  library(rsatscan) # important to make `{wowi}` access `{rsatscan}`-specific eviroment #> rsatscan only does anything useful if you have SaTScan #> See http://www.satscan.org/ for free access  #### Configure SaTScan ---- do.call(   what = ww_configure_satscan,   args = list(     filename = "Locality",     params_dir = directory,     satscan_version = "10.3.2",     .scan_for = "high-low-rates"   ) )  ## Show file's content ---- file.show(file.path(tmp, "input-files/Locality.prm"))

title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition ‚Äî ww_run_satscan
text: Detect statistically significant spatial clusters acute malnutrition rates, including high-high--low clusters. ww_run_satscan() wrapper function interacts SaTScan GUI via {rsatscan} package. internally calls ww_wrangle_data() ww_configure_satscan(), allowing users skip two steps workflow instead call ww_run_satscan() directly.

title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition ‚Äî ww_run_satscan
code: ww_run_satscan(   .data,   filename = NULL,   dir = character(),   params_dir = dir,   sslocation = character(),   ssbatchfilename = character(),   satscan_version,   .by_area = FALSE,   .scan_for = c("high-rates", "high-low-rates"),   .gam_based = c("wfhz", "muac", "combined"),   latitude,   longitude,   area = NULL,   cleanup = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition ‚Äî ww_run_satscan
text: .data data frame object wrangled using mwana::mw_wrangle_*() functions. filename Optional. Used single-area analysis. Used identify analysis area. string quoted. dir quoted string folder directory files saved. params_dir quoted string folder directory parameters file (produced function) saved. Defaults value dir. sslocation quoted string indicating path SaTScan GUI installation. varies depending operating system (OS). macOS, typically "/Applications/SaTScan.app/Contents/app"; Windows, "C:/Program Files/SaTScan". ssbatchfilename quoted string specifying SaTScan batch file name. macOS, use "satscan"; Windows, use "SaTScanBatch64". satscan_version quoted string indicating version SaTScan installed user's computer. See ww_configure_satscan() details. .by_area Logical. TRUE, area-wise scan done. Defaults FALSE. .scan_for quoted string indicating type clusters scan . scan clusters high rates , set .scan_for = "high-rates". scan high low rates, set .scan_for = "high-low-rates". .gam_based quoted string indicating criterion used define acute malnutrition. used identify right vector flagged values identified, excluded analysis. Defaults wfhz. latitude Geographical coordinates. unquoted string variable containing x-axis, also known latitude (east-west direction). variable must named "latitude". longitude Geographical coordinates. unquoted string variable containing y-axis, also know longitude (north-south direction). variable must named "longitude". area unquoted string variable containing analysis areas iteration. cleanup Logical. TRUE, deletes SaTScan output files directory function runs. verbose Logical. TRUE, displays SaTScan results R console run batch mode. especially useful scan takes long time.

title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition ‚Äî ww_run_satscan
text: set SaTScan output files, saved specified directory. full file names depend filename argument: filename.txt: plain-text summary results. filename.clustermap.html: interactive HTML map showing detected clusters, red bubbles high-rate clusters blue low-rate clusters. Shapefiles: collection spatial files suitable use GIS software.

title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition ‚Äî ww_run_satscan
text: geographical coordinates must provided latitude longitude values. input data uses different variable names, must renamed accordingly; otherwise, analysis aborted. Latitude corresponds X-axis (east-west direction), longitude X-axis (north-south direction).

title: Run SaTScan for Bernoulli purely spatial scan to detect statistically significant clusters of acute malnutrition ‚Äî ww_run_satscan
code: ## Wrangle data with `{mwana}` ---- x <- anthro |>   dplyr::rename(longitude = y, latitude = x) |>   mwana::mw_wrangle_wfhz(     sex = sex,     .recode_sex = TRUE,     weight = weight,     height = height   ) |>   mwana::define_wasting(     zscores = wfhz,     .by = "zscores",     oedema = oedema   ) #> ================================================================================  #' ## Given a temporary directory ---- tmp <- withr::local_tempdir() directory <- file.path(tmp, "input-files")  ## Run satscan ---- library(rsatscan) # important to make `{wowi}` access `{rsatscan}`-specific eviroment  if (file.exists("/Applications/SaTScan.app/Contents/app/satscan")) {   results <- ww_run_satscan(     .data = x,     filename = "Locality",     dir = directory,     sslocation = "/Applications/SaTScan.app/Contents/app",     ssbatchfilename = "satscan",     satscan_version = "10.3.2",     .scan_for = "high-low-rates",     .gam_based = "wfhz",     latitude = latitude,     longitude = longitude,     .by_area = FALSE,     area = NULL,     verbose = FALSE,     cleanup = FALSE   ) }

what: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory ‚Äî ww_wrangle_data
title: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory ‚Äî ww_wrangle_data
text: SaTScan's Bernoulli-based spatial scan requires input data split cases, controls, geographical coordinates files, saved format readable software, placed directory can access. ww_wrangle_data() convenient function designed task. assumes input anthropometric data pre-processed using {mwana} data wrangling functions.

title: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory ‚Äî ww_wrangle_data
code: ww_wrangle_data(   .data,   latitude,   longitude,   filename = character(),   dir = character(),   .gam_based = c("wfhz", "muac", "combined") )

title: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory ‚Äî ww_wrangle_data
text: .data data frame object wrangled using mwana::mw_wrangle_*() functions. latitude Geographical coordinates. unquoted string variable containing Y-axis, also known latitude (north-south direction). variable must named "latitude". longitude Geographical coordinates. unquoted string variable containing X-axis, also know longitude (east-west direction). variable must named "latitude". filename quoted string identifying analysis area. dir quoted string folder directory files saved. .gam_based quoted string indicating criterion used define acute malnutrition. used identify right vector flagged values identified, excluded analysis. Defaults wfhz.

title: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory ‚Äî ww_wrangle_data
text: Three files created saved user-defined directory specified dir argument: .cas file cases, .ctl controls, .geo file geographical coordinates. full filenames incorporate use-defined filename string. .cas .ctl files two columns: first containing survey cluster enumeration area IDs, second containing 1s, representing either cases controls, respectively. length .cas file depends number positive acute malnutrition cases (gam == 1), .ctl file number negative cases (gam == 0). .geo file three columns: cluster enumeration area IDs, latitude, longitude.

title: Prepare SaTScan-required input data files for Bernoulli spatial scan analysis and save them in a user-defined working directory ‚Äî ww_wrangle_data
code: ## Given a temporary directory ---- tmp <- withr::local_tempdir() directory <- file.path(tmp, "input-files")  ## Wrangle data with `{mwana}` ---- x <- anthro |>   dplyr::rename(longitude = y, latitude = x) |>   mwana::mw_wrangle_wfhz(     sex = sex,     .recode_sex = TRUE,     weight = weight,     height = height   ) |>   mwana::define_wasting(     zscores = wfhz,     .by = "zscores",     oedema = oedema   ) #> ================================================================================  ## Apply the function ---- ww_wrangle_data(   .data = x,   filename = "Locality",   dir = directory,   .gam_based = "wfhz",   latitude = latitude,   longitude = longitude ) #> [1] "/tmp/RtmpYJ0E4k/file2464337ea542/input-files/Locality"  ## Show created files ---- list.files(file.path(tmp, "input-files")) #> [1] "Locality.cas" "Locality.ctl" "Locality.geo"  ## Display each files' content ---- file.show(file.path(tmp, "input-files/Locality.cas")) file.show(file.path(tmp, "input-files/Locality.ctl")) file.show(file.path(tmp, "input-files/Locality.geo"))
